title: German I
description: As the first in a series of six language courses, this course invites students without prior knowledge of German to explore the basic features of the German language. Supported by audiovisual aids, students will receive intensive practice in spoken and written German through interactive class work, homework and online exercises. They will become familiar with the basic concepts of German grammar and learn how to interact in some simple everyday situations.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, the student should be able to deal with some simple daily situations in German such as greeting somebody and exchanging basic personal information with someone in a social gathering, talking about languages and professions, making assumptions, talking about preferences for food and drinks and going shopping.
syllabus: GERM1000    The course covers the first 3 units of the textbook “Kontakte, German I and German II”.   Chapter Topics Culture Structures   Einführung A (Introduction A) requests names clothes and colours greetings numbers first names colours as symbols German way of counting German way of writing A.1 Giving instructions: Polite commands A.2 What’s your name? The verb heißen A.3 The German case system A.4 Grammatical gender: Nouns and pronouns A.5 Addressing people: Sie versus du   Einführung B (Introduction B) The classroom Descriptions Our body Our family Weather and seasons Nationality and origins What is important in life? Weather and climate The location of Germany in Europe B.1 Definite and indefinite articles B.2 Who are you? The verb sein B.3 What do you have? The verb haben B.4 Plural forms of nouns B.5 Personal pronouns B.6 Origins: Woher kommen Sie? B.7 Possessive adjectives: mein and dein/Ihr   Chapter 1 Spare time School and university Daily routine Personal information Leisure time German school system 1.1 The present tense 1.2 Expressing likes and dislikes : gern/nicht gern 1.3 Telling Time 1.4 Word order in statements 1.5 Separable préfix verbs 1.6 Word order in questions
required_readings: Textbook: (available at The Commercial Press University Bookstore) • Tschirner, Nikolai, Terrell (2012) Kontakte, German I & German II, Singapore: McGraw-Hill.   Readings & references: • Reimann, Monika (2001) Essential grammar of German with exercises. Ismaning: Hueber  • Dodd, Bill et al. (1996) Modern German grammar: a practical guide. London: Routledge  • A desk-size bilingual dictionary, such as Langenscheidt, Collins or Duden-Oxford (pocket-size dictionaries are not recommended).  Web-based learning support:  • Beolingus online dictionary (English-German: http://dict.tu-chemnitz.de/) • Leo online dictionary (English-Chinese, English German www.leo.org) • Please refer to the Blackboard sites for GERM1000 and GERM0000 for online exercises and further materials

title: Germany Today
description: Germany was a once divided nation with complex historical background and rich culture which continuously attracts international interest. This course investigates trends and developments in contemporary German culture and society from a cross-cultural perspective, taking into consideration the historical events of different generations in Germany. Students will be encouraged to compare and critically analyze the reflections about Germany and their own society. The course content will be presented by up-to-date audiovisual materials. No knowledge of German is required.

title: German II
requirements: 1. Not for students who have taken GERM2001,2050(1010),3000,3001,3002,3050(2010) or 3051(3010);2. Prerequisite: GERM1000 (1001).
description: Building on the knowledge acquired in GERM1000, this course aims to further develop students’ ability to communicate in German in various everyday situations. It also seeks to give students a taste of German culture and invites them to explore cultural differences. Through intensive practice students will develop more confidence in interacting in German while further expanding and solidifying their understanding of the basic grammar and pronunciation patterns.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, the student should be able to deal with some simple daily situations in German such as  - Shopping in a supermarket - Talking about family and relatives - Discussing daily routines and leisure activities - Giving/receiving directions and telling time
syllabus: GERM1002       Course Content: the course will cover units 4 to 7 of Tangram Aktuell 1 (vol. 1 and 2)       4 Im Supermarkt In the supermarket  - Shopping in the supermarket - Finding your way around the supermarket  - Asking politely for advice and assistance   - Dative case of personal pronouns and locations  - Imperative - Food, measurements and packaging    5 Arbeit und Freizeit Work and leisure  - Discussing advantages and disadvantages - Leisure activities  - Telling time and making appointments - Dates - Expressing frequency  - Modal verbs  - Locations and directions - Expressing time - Ordinal numbers   6 Familie und Haushalt Family and household  - Family and relatives - Discussing household chores  - Daily routines - Possesive articles - Separable prefix verbs - two-way prepositions - conjunctions (und, aber, oder)   7 Berlin! Berlin! - Giving/receiving directions - Speaking about past events - Discussing favorite places - Locations and directions - The present perfect tense - Past perfect participle - Personal pronouns in the accusative case
required_readings: Textbook: (available at The Commercial Press University Bookstore) • Tschirner, Nikolai, Terrell (2012) Kontakte, German I & German II, Singapore: McGraw-Hill.   Readings & references: • Reimann, Monika (2001) Essential grammar of German with exercises. Ismaning: Hueber  • Dodd, Bill et al. (1996) Modern German grammar: a practical guide. London: Routledge  • Beolingus online dictionary (English-German: http://dict.tu-chemnitz.de/) • A desk-size bilingual dictionary, such as Langenscheidt, Collins or Duden-Oxford (pocket-size dictionaries are not recommended). • Please refer to the Blackboard site for GERM2000 for further materials and online-exercises
recommended_readings: Textbook: (available at The Commercial Press University Bookstore) • Tschirner, Nikolai, Terrell (2012) Kontakte, German I & German II, Singapore: McGraw-Hill.   Readings & references: • Reimann, Monika (2001) Essential grammar of German with exercises. Ismaning: Hueber  • Dodd, Bill et al. (1996) Modern German grammar: a practical guide. London: Routledge  • Beolingus online dictionary (English-German: http://dict.tu-chemnitz.de/) • A desk-size bilingual dictionary, such as Langenscheidt, Collins or Duden-Oxford (pocket-size dictionaries are not recommended). • Please refer to the Blackboard site for GERM2000 for further materials and online-exercises

title: German III
requirements: 1. Not for students who have taken GERM3000,3001,3002,3050(2010) or 3051(3010);2. Prerequisite: GERM2000(1002) or 2050(1010).
description: This course aims to further enhance students’ communication skills in the four language domains listening, speaking, reading and writing. Students are expected to communicate confidently in a wider range of social interactions including more formal situations and simple professional contexts as well as reporting past events and sharing experience. At the end of this course, students will have completed a proficiency level comparable to level A1 of the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages (CEFR).
outcome: Upon completion of the course, the student should be able to deal with a range of situations in German such as  • discussing one’s living situation; • discussing holiday and vacation; • reporting about Germany and one’s own country; • talking about health and nutrition; • talking about events of the past.
syllabus: GERM2001       Course Content: The course will cover 4 units of the textbook Studio D A1.     Lesson   Speech acts   Grammar    Station 2 Revision of Einheit 5-8     9. Ferien und Urlaub (Holiday and vacation) - Talk about holidays and vacation in different European countries - Describe an accident - Describe one’s own vacation - Perfect tense of regular and irregular verbs   10. Essen und Trinken (Food and drinks) - Shopping: handle conversations in a shop, such as request for items, ask for prices - Talk about food, likes and dislikes - Understand and explain a recipe - Frequency: jeden Tag, manchmal, nie - Question Word: welch- - Comparatives: viel, gut, gern   11. Kleidung und Wetter (Clothing and weather) - Talk about clothes - Buy clothes - Give information on colours and sizes - Understand weather information - Talk about the weather - Adjectives in Akkusativ – indefinite articles - Demonstrative pronouns: dieser – dieses – diese/ der – das - die - Personal pronoun: es   12. Körper und Gesundheit (Body and health)  - Name body parts - Express health problems and where it hurts - Give recommendations and instructions - Write a letter - Imperatives - Modal Verb dürfen - Personal pronouns in Akkusativ
required_readings: Textbook: (available at University Bookstore)  Tangram Aktuell 2, Lektion 1-4, by Dallapiazza, Rosa-Maria / von Jan, Eduard / Schönherr, Till, Ismaning: Hueber Verlag 2009  Readings & references:  • Reimann, Monika (2001): Essential grammar of German with exercises. Ismaning: Hueber  • Dodd, Bill et al. (1996): Modern German grammar: a practical guide. London: Routledge  • Beolingus online dictionary (English-German: http://dict.tu-chemnitz.de/) • A desk-size bilingual dictionary, such as Langenscheidt, Collins or Duden-Oxford (pocket-size dictionaries are not recommended). • Please refer to the Moodle site for GERM2001 for further materials and exercises

Ismaning: Hueber  • Dodd, Bill et al. (1996): Modern German grammar: a practical guide. London: Routledge  • Beolingus online dictionary (English-German: http://dict.tu-chemnitz.de/) • A desk-size bilingual dictionary, such as Langenscheidt, Collins or Duden-Oxford (pocket-size dictionaries are not recommended). • Please refer to the Moodle site for GERM2001 for further materials and exercises

title: Sounds of German
description: This course is an introduction to the phonetic system of the German language, with an emphasis on the similarities and differences between German and English pronunciation. Illustrations and examples will be taken from modern spoken German. Students learning German are encouraged to take this course.
outcome: - To learn about different forms of Sounds in the German language  e.g. dialogues, prose, poems, rhymes, songs etc. - to get acquainted with the German phonetic structure - to improve pronunciation and intonation - to speak better German - to have fun with the German language
syllabus: First contact + Adjustment of standard  The 5 vowels (long and short) The long vowel of O and E and the endings The Umlauts : Ä, Ö and Ü and  the Diphthongs au / eu / ei  The sounds of “ch” and “sch” The sounds of “R”  Holiday (Chung Yeung Festival) The sounds of the numbers   Mid Term Test  The melody   The accent and the rhythm Combination and changes  The tongue-twisters  Final Test
required_readings: Hand-outs will be given during class, contents will include phonetic instructions, reading materials, and homework exercises. There is no need to buy a text-book, although the course of instruction is based on the German phonetic Video Course “SIMSALABIM”. [Langenscheidt: Ursula Hirschfeld und Kerstin Reinke]

title: German I & II
description: (Please read the Study Scheme Note.) This is a summer intensive German language course for beginners, covering the full syllabus of GERM1000 and 2000.

title: Exploring German Literature
description: This course is designed to introduce students to some most representative figures in German literature. Emphasis is placed on the critical and analytical reading of their major works in English or Chinese version.All readings and discussions are in English. No knowledge of German is required.
outcome: By the end of the course students demonstrate the ability to  • classify the important periods, writers and works of German literature. • understand and analyze literary works as reflections of the social and political contexts of their time. • distinguish various literary forms, such as drama, novel, poetry and short stories.
syllabus: GERM2100      Topic Contents / fundamental concepts   Periods of German Literature Overview over the development from the beginnings to present   The beginnings “Song of the Nibelungs” (Das Nibelungenlied) - ~1200 - loyalty and betrayal as the fundamental concepts in medieval epics   Literature in the period of Enlightenment (Aufklärung)  -  Lessing (1729-1781), “Nathan the Wise” (Nathan der Weise) – theater to promote religious tolerance   Storm and Stress (Sturm und Drang)  The young Goethe (1749-1832): “The Sorrows of Young Werther”  (Die Leiden des jungen Werthers) –passionate individualism    Weimar Classic: Goethe and Schiller The birth of a national German literature – breaking the barriers of human existence (Goethe “Faust”) and struggle against oppression (Schiller “Intrigues and Love” - Kabale und Liebe).    Romanticism Kleist (1797-1856): “The Beggar-woman of Locarno” (Das Bettelweib von Locarno) – Eichendorff (1788-1857): “Moon Night” (Mondnacht) - the irrational and the mystic   Young Germany The making of modern social drama: Büchner (1813-1837): Woyzeck   Expressionism Kafka (1883-1924), “Metamorphosis” (Die Verwandlung)   Swiss-German Literature Dürrenmatt (1921-1990): “The Visit of the old Lady” (Der Besuch der alten Dame)   Post-unification German Literature Dealing with the past (fascism and neonazism) – Grass (1927- ) “Crabwalk” (Im Krebsgang)   Poetry after 1945 Literature and the Holocaust: Paul Celan (1920-1970): “Death fugue” (Todesfuge)
required_readings: Excerpts of the selected works are put online on moodle  Handouts
recommended_readings: Watanabe-O’Kelly, Helen (ed) (1997) The Cambridge history of German literature. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. Kim, Vivian (1992) A concise history of German literature to 1900. Columbia: Camden House. Stoehr, Ingo Roland (2001) German literature of the twentieth century: from aestheticism to postmodernism. Rochester, N.Y.: Camden House.  All books are put on reserve in the University Library.

title: German Cinema
description: German cinema has always captured the attention of the world. This course is an introduction to the history and major developments in German cinema. It explores the language of cinema and the aesthetic strategies used by filmmakers. Through analyses and discussions about the making and content of the films, students will not only get to know the films as entertaining art, but embed them in a social and historical context. Films are screened outside class hours. All films are with English subtitles, all readings and discussions in English. No knowledge of German is required.

title: German IV
requirements: 1. Not for students who have taken GERM3001,3002,3050(2010) or 3051(3010);2. Prerequisite: GERM2001
description: This course aims at increasing students' communicative fluency in oral and written German. Using a variety of classroom activities and multimedia, students will build up their competence in the four language domains listening, speaking, reading and writing. Through intensive practice they will be able to communicate in a wide range of social situations with the appropriate awareness of the pragmatic rules involved. Students receive guidance in the process of composing longer texts displaying a range of registers and styles relating to past, present and future events.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, the student should be able to:  - Talk about his or her learning biography - Talk about family and related issues - Plan or book a trip in German - Speak about hobbies.
syllabus: GERM2002       Course Content: The course will cover 4 units of the textbook Studio D A2.      Lesson   Speech acts   Grammar    1. Sprachen und Biografien - Talking about languages - Giving reasons - Talking about one’s own learning biography  - Subordinate clause with ‘weil’ - Comparatives - Comparison of ‘wie’ and ‘als’ - Superlatives: ‘am höchsten’, ‘am weitesten’   2. Familienalbum - Talking about family and family celebrations  - Describing photos and persons - Congratulating someone, inviting someone - Expressing views  - Possessive articles in ‘Dativ’ - Adjectives in ‘Dativ’ - Subordinate clauses with ‘dass’ - Genitive    3. Reisen und Mobilität - Talking about a journey - Expressing assumptions: wahrscheinlich/ vielleicht - Reading travel itineraries - Planning and booking a trip - Expressing contraries: aber - Expressing alternatives: oder  Modal verb: sollen   4. Aktiv in der Freizeit  - Talking about leisure time activities - Speaking about hobbies and    interests - Reacting positively or negatively  - Reflexive pronouns - Verbs with prepositions - Indefinite words

Ismaning: Hueber  • Dodd, Bill et al. (1996) Modern German grammar: a practical guide. London: Routledge • A desk-size bilingual dictionary, such as Langenscheidt, Collins or Duden-Oxford (pocket-size dictionaries are not recommended). Web-based learning support: • Online homework can be found on Blackboard https://elearn.cuhk.edu.hk • Beolingus online dictionary (English-German: http://dict.tu-chemnitz.de/) • Leo online dictionary (German/English /Chinese www.leo.org ) • Please refer to the Blackboard sites GERM2001 and GERM0000 for online exercises and further materials
recommended_readings: Textbook: (available at Commercial Press University Bookstore) • Tschirner, Nikolai, Terrell (2013) Kontakte, German III and German IV  Readings & references: • Reimann, Monika (2001) Essential grammar of German with exercises. Ismaning: Hueber  • Dodd, Bill et al. (1996) Modern German grammar: a practical guide. London: Routledge • A desk-size bilingual dictionary, such as Langenscheidt, Collins or Duden-Oxford (pocket-size dictionaries are not recommended). Web-based learning support: • Online homework can be found on Blackboard https://elearn.cuhk.edu.hk • Beolingus online dictionary (English-German: http://dict.tu-chemnitz.de/) • Leo online dictionary (German/English /Chinese www.leo.org ) • Please refer to the Blackboard sites GERM2001 and GERM0000 for online exercises and further materials

title: German V
requirements: 1. Not for students who have taken GERM3002 or 3051(3010);2. Prerequisite: GERM3000 (2002) or GERM3050 (2010)
description: This course focuses on the further development of communication skills in German with emphasis on the expression of personal views and the training of argumentative strategies. The course will also engage students in critical reflections on various aspects of life in German-speaking countries and their own social environment. Students will be guided to analyze various types of data to support their views. They will learn how to express their wishes and aspirations using the appropriate registers.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, the student should be able to: - describe locations while reporting about features of nature, geography and scenery in Germany. - discuss causes and consequences from various perspectives in discussions of family relationships. - report about events of the past, both in discussion of individual experience and in (re-)narrating stories. - identify basic generic elements of a fairy tale comparing/contrasting these elements across versions.
syllabus: GERM3001       Course Content: The course will cover the units 5 - 8 of the textbook Studio D A2.     Lesson   Speech acts   Grammar    Unit 5: “Medien” Media - talking about media - writing personal messages (sms, email) - making a complaint (about quality) - indirect questions in subordinate sentences: if-sentences, indirect questions with interrogatives - adjectives without article -indefinite pronouns: „niemand, wenige, viele, alle“   Unit 6: „Ausgehen“ Going out - leisure time activities – expressing preferences - reading a restaurant menu - ordering in a restaurant - talking about dating and contacts - Personal pronouns in Dativ („mit dir, mit ihm“) - Relative clause, relative pronouns in Nominativ and Akkusativ   Unit 7: “Zu Hause” At home - talking about living in the city and in the countryside - analyzing property advertisements - looking for an apartment - planning to move house - reporting accidents in the household - modal verbs in simple past - subordinate clauses with “als”   Unit 8: “Kultur erleben” Experience culture - talking about cultural interests - planning a city tour - going to the theatre - talking and writing about events in the past - temporal adverbs “damals, früher / heute,jetzt“ - verbs in simple past - perfect tense and simple past
required_readings: Textbooks: • Reader with texts will be handed out in class • Link, Caroline (1996) Jenseits der Stille (DVD) (available at Amazon and in the CUHK library). Purchase of this material is mandatory.
recommended_readings: Readings &references: • Dodd, Bill et al. (1996) Modern German grammar: a practical guide. London: Routledge • Reimann, Monika (2001) Essential grammar of German with exercises. Ismaning: Hueber Available in the Swindon book store on campus) • Beolingus online dictionary (English-German: http://dict.tu-chemnitz.de/) • A desk-size bilingual dictionary, such as Langenscheidt, Collins or Duden-Oxford (pocket-size dictionaries are not recommended. Web-based learning support: • Additional material will be available on the course website (Blackboard)

title: German VI
requirements: 1. Not for students who have taken GERM3051 (3010).;2. Prerequisite: GERM3001.
description: This course builds on the knowledge acquired through previous German language courses. It aims at leading students to a proficiency level comparable to the threshold from A2 to B1 of the Common European Framework for Languages (CEFR), becoming “independent users” of German. To achieve this goal, students will be encouraged to work project-based through independent or collaborative work with their peers. At the end of this course students will have mastered the most important grammar features of German and be able to communicate effectively in a wide range of everyday situations and a number of professional contexts. They will be able to use their oral and written language skills to relate to, reflect on and analyze past and current issues involving the German-speaking societies.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, participants will be able to use German according to the level A2 of the Common European Framework. This includes written and oral interaction.
syllabus: GERM3002       Course Content: The course will cover units 9 to 12 of Studio D vol. 2.     Lesson   Speech acts   Grammar    9 Arbeitswelten Work environments - talking about career paths and career options - analyse job advertisements and CVs - telephone messages - polite requests - connecting sentences with “denn” and “weil” - the verb “werden” (to become) - word formation: verb to noun - wishes, politeness “hätte“, „könnte“   10 Feste und Geschenke Festivals and presents - talking about festivals and customs - talking about presents - compare festivals in German-speaking countries and other countries - prepositions with Dativ - verbs with Dativ objects - verbs with Dativ and Akkusativ objects   11 Mit allen Sinnen With all senses - recognizing emotions - expressing emotions - reacting on emotions - talking about a movie - indefinite pronouns “einige, manche” - verbs with prepositions in Akkusativ or Dativ (“liegen – legen”) - understanding Genitiv - relative clauses: „in, mit“ + Dativ   12 Erfindungen und Erfinder Inventions and inventors - understanding the manuals of products and inventions - working with texts - talking about purpose - describing processes - subordinate clauses with “um … zu” and “damit” - passive voice (das Passiv) with „werden / wurden“
required_readings: • Reader with texts will be handed out in class • Link, Caroline (1996) Jenseits der Stille (DVD) (available at Amazon and in the CUHK library).  Readings & references: • Gschossmann-Hendershot, Elke & Feuerle, Lois (2009) Schaum's Outline of German Grammar 4th ed. McGraw-Hill. Available in the University Library • Dodd, Bill et al. (1996) Modern German grammar: a practical guide. London: Routledge  • Reimann, Monika (2001) Essential grammar of German with exercises. Ismaning: Hueber Leo online dictionary: www.dict.leo.org • Beolingus online dictionary (English-German: http://dict.tu-chemnitz.de/) • Leo Online dictionary www.leo.org • A desk-size bilingual dictionary, such as Langenscheidt, Collins or Duden-Oxford (pocket-size dictionaries are not recommended). Web-based learning support: • Additional material can be found on the CUHK e-learning platform for the course.
recommended_readings: • Reader with texts will be handed out in class • Link, Caroline (1996) Jenseits der Stille (DVD) (available at Amazon and in the CUHK library).  Readings & references: • Gschossmann-Hendershot, Elke & Feuerle, Lois (2009) Schaum's Outline of German Grammar 4th ed. McGraw-Hill. Available in the University Library • Dodd, Bill et al. (1996) Modern German grammar: a practical guide. London: Routledge  • Reimann, Monika (2001) Essential grammar of German with exercises. Ismaning: Hueber Leo online dictionary: www.dict.leo.org • Beolingus online dictionary (English-German: http://dict.tu-chemnitz.de/) • Leo Online dictionary www.leo.org • A desk-size bilingual dictionary, such as Langenscheidt, Collins or Duden-Oxford (pocket-size dictionaries are not recommended). Web-based learning support: • Additional material can be found on the CUHK e-learning platform for the course.

title: German Conversation
description: This course aims to enhance students’ oral communication skills in German. Through selected student-oriented stimuli and topics related to social issues and contemporary affairs, students will practice the expression and exchange of personal views and ideas. Classroom activities may include in-class activities such as dialogue, role-play, narration, speech, group discussion, debate and multimedia activities. Emphasis will be placed on oral practice and an interactive learning environment with a view to helping students build confidence and develop fluency in using the language, to speak spontaneously in social interaction and acquire conversational techniques commonly used in a German-speaking environment.
outcome: This course is designed to help you strengthen and expand your conversational skills. To broaden and improve your capacity in German, this course focuses on the particular subset of language skills that are fundamental to conversation. Specifically, you will:  - Improve your ability to engage in spontaneous oral discussion on basic themes and to respond appropriately in context-specific conversational settings - Expand and personalize your active vocabulary knowledge in common areas of conversation - Improve your listening comprehension skills and further your ability to understand spoken language.
syllabus: -Einführung -Freizeit und Hobbys -Tägliches Leben  -Interview mit Austauschstudenten -Mode und Einkaufen  -Feste und Musik -Leben und Tod: Michael Jackson und Pina Bausch  -Beziehungen  -Sport oder Tiere -Essen und Trinken  -Reisen und Urlaub  -Reisen und Urlaub -Final sketch
required_readings: So geht’s. Fertigkeitstraining Grundstufe Deutsch. Fischer-Mitziviris, Janke-Papanikolaou. Klett (2001). [ISBN 3-12-675575-5]   A good dictionary (Langenscheidt, Oxford-Collins, Duden-Oxford et al.)   A small notebook (or electronic document) for Vokabelheft
recommended_readings: Recommended materials: • Reinmann, Monika (2001) Essential grammar of German with exercises. Ismaning: Hueber  • Dodd, Bill et al. (1996) Modern German grammar: a practical guide. London: Routledge  • A desk-size bilingual dictionary, such as Langenscheidt, Collins or Duden-Oxford (pocket-size dictionaries are not recommended).

title: German for Professional Communication
description: The course aims at introducing the basic features of spoken and written business-related and official German language use. Through different types of activities that enhance reading, listening, speaking and writing skills, the students will be able to handle different kinds of business-related and official situations in German confidently. Emphasis is put on the language use of German in genuine professional occasions such as telephone communication, reading and writing official letters, reading job offers, submitting job application, and preparing and attending job interviews.

title: German III & IV
requirements: 1.Not for students who have taken GERM2001,3000 (2002),3001,3002 or 3051;2.Prerequisite: GERM2000 (1002) or GERM2050 (1010)
description: This is a summer intensive German language course, covering the full syllabus of GERM2001 and 3000.

title: German V & VI
requirements: Not for students who have taken GERM3001 or 3002.;Prerequisite: GERM3000 (2002) or GERM3050 (2010).
description: This is a summer intensive German language course, covering the full syllabus of GERM3001 and 3002.

title: German through Fairy Tales
description: This course is a combination of content learning and language learning. Making use of folk tales, such as Grimm's fairy tales, legends and literary fairy tales, the students will enrich their understanding of the German language as well as their content knowledge about fairy tales and knowledge about German culture. The tales taught will be read in simplified versions in German. Content knowledge will be discussed in English.

title: Special Topics in German
description: This course aims at furthering students' understanding of selected area(s) of German language, literature or culture. Topics will vary from year to year. Offerings with different subtitles can be taken up for credit, up to a maximum of two times.

title: German VII
description: This course builds on the knowledge acquired through previous German language courses. It aims at leading students to a proficiency level comparable to the threshold at B1 of the Common European Framework for Languages (CEFR), becoming “independent users” of German. To achieve this goal, students will be encouraged to work with a communicative approach through independent or collaborative work with their peers. At the end of this course, students will have mastered most of the important grammar features of German and be able to communicate effectively in a wide range of everyday situations and a number of professional contexts. They will be able to use their oral and written language skills to relate to, reflect on and evaluate past and current issues involving the German-speaking societies.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, the student should be able to: • understand the main points of information in conversations and texts on familiar matters relating to work, school and leisure time, etc. when clear, standard language is used, • deal with most situations typically encountered when travelling in German-speaking countries, • express yourself simply and coherently when talking about familiar topics and areas of personal interest, • report on experiences and events, describe dreams, hopes and ambitions as well as make short statements and explanations.
syllabus: Lesson Speech Acts / Topics Grammar Culture   Module 1(Units 1-3) Describing people; Evaluating past events and rendering reports of past events; Talking about graphs and charts adjectives as nouns; n-declination; simple past tense; relative clauses in dative and with prepositions Friendship/traits of character; Professional life; Habitation    Module 2(Units 4-6) Conducting customer complaints; Making conjectures about the future and understanding opinion polls; Understanding, reacting to and rendering semi-official invitations conjunctions „obwohl“ and „trotzdem“; future tense (“Futur 1”); conjunction “falls” customer service; media and technology; invitation for a meal
required_readings: Menschen B1.1, Kursbuch mit DVD-Rom (course book) & Arbeitsbuch mit 2 Audio-CDs (workbook), Ismaning: Hueber Verlag. https://moodle.keep.edu.hk/ Announcements over the Blackboard site GERM0000
recommended_readings: • Leo online dictionary (English-Chinese, English German www.leo.org/ ) • Quizlet: https://quizlet.com/ • Nicos Weg: https://learngerman.dw.com/en/overview • Deutsch für dich: https://www.goethe.de/prj/dfd/en/home.cfm • Stadt der Wörter: https://www.goethe.de/en/spr/ueb/led.html
